body: I feel it's the users job, just like driving a car, before you get in and drive, it's your job to make sure its ina reasonalbe technical state. Personally feel that this is a won't fix.
Also I am sure there is specialised software out there that does it, we don't need to make syncthing a swiss army knife which does everything, but poorly.

Why should a sync tool not make as much use of the information at hand as possible? If it knows the disk has 5 GB remaining, why should it blindly try and download a 10 GB file only to waste bandwidth? Why should the user be expected to keep checking free disk space every few minutes when a machine could do it easily on their behalf?

It seems clear from #1790 that the database library will crash when disk space reaches zero. So why not have a simple check to avoid this happening? I'm not suggesting a complex system of disk quotas, just a simple "safety valve" mechanism that the user can turn on/off if he/she wishes.

Because there is no such thing as a simple check. Go stdlib does not provide a way to check this, meaning we dwell down into win32 api land for windows, some magic api for solaris and any other operating system syncthing will support in the future.

Why should syncthing not consume 100% of the space? Same like utorrent or chrome or whatever, it will consume as much space as possible.

I feel this is a lot of work for a limited benefit.

@AudriusButkevicius this is not work for a limited benefit. With syncthing someone could render another computer almost unusable by dropping a big file in a synced directory! For many users it's not an easy task to set up quotas to limit disk usage by syncthing...

Assuming we can detect the amount of space left on the device, what would we aim for as a limit? We may create temporary copies of (by default) up to 16 files when synchronizing them, so we would need to reserve space for at least copies of the 16 largest files in the repo to be sure a sync is going to work. But that could mean we want 100 GB of free space just to update a text file.

We could try to do the check just before copying a file, possibly, and skipping it if the amount of free space looks marginal (I recall trying something like this in a branch ages ago, I wonder what happened to that...). We'll try smaller files in that case (as we always try to sync the next file in the list if one file fails for whatever reason), so we might still get very close to full filesystem - basically as close as the smallest file we have in the repo.

We could do as above (check before each file) but stop completely once it doesn't fit. That'd probably be fairly safe (barring the multiple-files-being-synced-in-paralell thing that may need handling) but also means we wouldn't be syncing stuff that we otherwise could have been.

Absolute values are obviously no good (8 GB free would be a good warning limit on my photo folder, but not on a phone), percentages likewise (5% of my data pool is still 900 GB)...

User configurable, possibly, but the less we need to ask for the better... And it needs to actually work. I.e. whatever method we choose should mean we _don't_ fill the disk, which would not be the case by for example just going with a 95% full limit as we might still try to sync a file that's 6% of the total disk size.

If we end up with something advanced (at least space for the file we're going to sync, plus 50% overhead, but at least 10 MiB, unless that's more than 10% of the disk space, but only for folders larger than x...) this needs to be understandable to the user...

(This is not a rethorical question... Contrary to Audrius I think this might be a `help-wanted` but then we at least need to clarify how it should work. :)

I think having a resonable percentage as default (I'd vote for 10%) should be good and than this could be an advanced option. If a user sets this value to 0%, then it is out of the hands of syncthing.

Your idea of checking before copying a file and if it wouldn't fit just skipping it, sounds reasonable.

How to handle the temporary copies, I do not know. Question is, where are they stored? In /temp on Linux? Then you need the space there. And reserving space for the 16 largest files in a repo sound as too much. And what happens, if I have 5 shared directories on my device? Is it 80 temporary files then?
I know many people who are happily operating within 10% of their disk limit. On a 1TB drive that's still 100GB spare. They would be pissed if Syncthing refused to synchronize under those conditions.
Will Syncthing behave if the disk gets full, or could it half-write a file which then looks different to the files on other nodes, and propagate back?
@jpjp that can happen, however I think the db would be corrupted sooner and syncthing will exit. There is a patch on the way that will exit when free disk space < 1GB (configurable).

This latter presumes that the db and sync folder are in the same
filesystem. Maybe true for small cases but not at all certain for anything
serious. I have dozens of filesystems on most machines, including laptops,
because zfs makes it easy and worthwhile; sync points are a good example.

Another worm of opening this can: if we hit some putative limit, could we
react by pruning .stversions somehow? This can at least be delegated back
to a user extension, but it's all more complexity than seems worthwhile.

@dcarosone I think this feature should not be too intelligent. It should just prevent filling up the file system. If the limit is hit it would be sufficient to inform the user and then the user has to react.

I agree with @cs42, just a simple warning box is enough. Also it would be great if Syncthing does not go crazy during this time, e.g. if the out of space is for a few days: temporary files are usually deleted every 24h, so it will then download the same file again only to find that there is not enough space. Maybe Syncthing can disconnect itself from the other devices?

@dcarosone sounds interesting, but I believe we should simply exit as a default. Feel free to open a new issue to propose accommodating actions. However, I could see that we start cleaning up files in .stversions because another process is filling the disk, this is not what I want at least.

@uok It will simply exit because changes to the filesystem can increase the size of the db.

@Zillode I never have ST and the shared folders on the same this, so the DB will always have enough space. I also do not want automatic cleanup of .stversions, since this is sometimes the last resort to get an important file back. An exit will be the safest of all ways, but the user has to know what's going on (e.g. automatic restart scripts?)
